thread.title: Miller: Utley wakes up Dodgers with old-school slide
thread.title_full: Miller: Utley wakes up Dodgers with old-school slide - Press Enterprise

author: JEFF MILLER
title: Miller: Utley wakes up Dodgers with old-school slide
text:
By JEFF MILLER / STAFF COLUMNIST
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: 10:56 p.m. Miller: Utley wakes up Dodgers with old-school slide Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT The Dodgers' Chase Utley breaks up a double play - and the right leg of the Mets shortstop Ruben Tejada - in Game 2 of the National League Division Series at Dodger Stadium on Saturday. MICHAEL GOULDING, STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Related article » LOS ANGELES – I was thinking that maybe this was an incredible sight, some sort unimaginable scene no one could have possibly expected to witness.
Not in a million years.
Then I realized I, of all people, had in fact witnessed this before and barely 365 days ago, too.
That’s when the Angels opened up a division series at home, against an opponent they were generally forecast to beat, and their hitters performed as if they were standing at the plate armed with loaves of bread.
Now, here were the Dodgers, 15 innings into their National League Division Series, at home, against the underdog Mets, having scored only twice up to that point while hitting a collective .216.
Then Chase Utley delivered the big blow – while skidding on his rear-end – significantly changing the course of a game and a series.
The old-school Dodger made an old-school move, taking out the Mets’ shortstop on a potential double play, the body block allowing the tying run to score and seemingly awakening a desperate team and an anxious stadium.
The resultant four-run rally lifted the Dodgers to a 5-2 victory, evening this series at one game apiece and igniting a debate about whether Utley was playing hard or recklessly.
“You play this game hard, but it’s never with the intention of hurting anybody,” teammate Howie Kendrick said. “I feel like Chase made a good baseball play there.”
Utley slid decidedly late, no question, sailing past second so dramatically that he was unable to even touch the base. That was his greatest crime.
But, in accordance to baseball’s famously unwritten rules, Utley was in the proximity of second, his slide – as tardy as it was – not something that’s terribly uncommon in this game.
Now, the fact Ruben Tejada, the shortstop who looked more like a slot receiver being cart-wheeled by a linebacker, suffered a fractured leg didn’t make the play any more pleasant. No one wants to see an athlete ever leave the playing field on a cart.
“That’s baseball,” Kendrick said. “He probably did slide late. ... It’s just kind of unfortunate the guy ended up getting hurt.”
Asked for his opinion of Utley’s slide, Mets manager Terry Collins said, “It broke my shortstop’s leg. That’s all I know.”
The whole exchange looked even worse because of the awkward positioning of Tejada, who had turned his back on the charging Utley to take the throw before, presumably, spinning to attempt to complete a double play that, by that point, had very little chance of actually happening.
In fact, everyone would soon learn, the double play never had any chance of happening. A replay review determined that Tejada had failed to make contact with second base, too, and Utley was ruled safe – on a play that, ironically enough, was anything but safe.
“There's a way to play the game hard, but only Chase knows going in there what his intent was," the Mets' David Wright said. “I have a problem with the play on a number of different levels, one being the slide itself. In my opinion, he wasn't anywhere close to the bag. He never touched the bag. I have a lot of questions.”
1 2 Next Page
